question:
Which military officer led the British forces in the Battle of Chinhat fought in 1857?

SSC CHSL 08/07/2024 (3rd Shift)
solution:
• The Battle of Chinhat was fought on 30 June 1857 near Lucknow during the Indian Rebellion of 1857.
  • Brigadier General Sir Henry Lawrence, the British Resident at Awadh, led the British forces in this battle.
  • He marched out from Lucknow to confront the rebel forces but was met with unexpectedly strong resistance.
  • The battle ended in a defeat for the British, forcing them to retreat to the Lucknow Residency.
  • Henry Lawrence was seriously wounded shortly after the battle and died on 4 July 1857.

Additional Information:

  • The Indian forces in the battle were led by Barkat Ahmad, a former British army officer.
  • The defeat at Chinhat marked the beginning of the Siege of Lucknow, one of the key events of the 1857 revolt.
  • This battle exposed the underestimation of rebel strength by British officers early in the revolt.

question:
Post 1857 revolt, the Peel Commission was set up to give recommendations on ____ reorganisation of British India.

Matriculation Level 25/06/2024 (Shift - 1)
solution:
• After the Revolt of 1857, the British realized the need to restructure their military system in India.
  • As a result, the Peel Commission was formed in 1859 under Sir William Peel.
  • Its main purpose was to recommend reforms in the British Indian Army to prevent future mutinies.
  • The commission emphasized increasing the number of European soldiers and decreasing dependence on Indian sepoys.
  • It also suggested a more balanced ratio between British and Indian troops and better training and discipline systems.

Additional Information:

  • One major change post-revolt was ending the rule of the East India Company; governance was transferred to the British Crown in 1858.
  • Other administrative reforms included the creation of the Secretary of State for India and the Indian Councils Act 1861.
  • The military restructuring aimed to ensure greater loyalty to the British Raj in future.

question:
Who among the following leaders led the Revolt of 1857 in Bihar?

SSC MTS 04/09/2023 (3rd Shift)
solution:
• The Revolt of 1857 in Bihar was led by Kunwar Singh, the Zamindar of Jagdishpur.
  • Despite being over 80 years old, he played a key leadership role against the British forces.
  • Kunwar Singh was known for his bravery and strategic warfare during the rebellion.
  • He successfully defeated British troops in several encounters and became a symbol of resistance in eastern India.
  • His leadership significantly inspired local participation in the rebellion from Bihar and surrounding regions.

Additional Information:

  • Kunwar Singh is often referred to as the "Lion of Bihar".
  • He continued the fight even after sustaining injuries, reportedly getting his own wounded hand amputated to prevent infection.
  • A memorial and university in his name — Veer Kunwar Singh University — exist today in Bihar.

question:
With reference to the Sepoy Mutiny of 1857, on which of the following dates did the soldiers at Meerut start their journey to Delhi?

SSC CGL 12/09/2024 (1st Shift)
solution:
• The Sepoy Mutiny of 1857 began at Meerut, where Indian soldiers (sepoys) rebelled against the British officers.
  • The revolt at Meerut started on the evening of 10 May 1857, when the sepoys broke open the jail, released fellow soldiers, and attacked British officers.
  • That night itself, the rebel soldiers marched towards Delhi, covering nearly 65 km.
  • The next day, on 11 May, they reached Delhi and persuaded Bahadur Shah Zafar to become the symbolic leader of the revolt.
  • This march from Meerut to Delhi was the turning point that gave the rebellion a pan-Indian character.

Additional Information:

  • The initial trigger was the introduction of greased cartridge rifles, which offended both Hindu and Muslim soldiers.
  • Prior events include Mangal Pandey’s revolt at Barrackpore on 29 March 1857, but the full-scale uprising began from Meerut on 10 May.
  • The British later termed this event as a mutiny, while Indian historians consider it the First War of Independence.

question:
The revolution of 1857 started in May from which of the following cantonments in India?

SSC CGL 26/09/2024 (1st Shift)
solution:
• The Revolt of 1857 began in Meerut cantonment on the evening of 10 May 1857.
  • The immediate cause was the refusal of sepoys to use the new Enfield rifles with cartridges rumored to be greased with cow and pig fat.
  • When 85 sepoys were court-martialled and imprisoned for disobedience, their fellow soldiers revolted, freed them, and attacked British officers.
  • This uprising at Meerut marked the official beginning of the revolt.
  • After the revolt, the soldiers marched to Delhi, reaching on 11 May, and declared Bahadur Shah Zafar as their emperor.

Additional Information:

  • The revolt later spread to other major centers such as Kanpur, Lucknow, Jhansi, and Bareilly.
  • Meerut's selection as the revolt's starting point was significant due to its large military presence and proximity to Delhi.
  • The Revolt of 1857 is also known as India’s First War of Independence.

question:
When did the first War of Indian Independence (Sepoy Mutiny) start?

SSC CHSL 02/07/2024 (4th Shift)
solution:
• The First War of Indian Independence, also known as the Sepoy Mutiny or Revolt of 1857, began in the year 1857.
  • It started on the evening of 10 May 1857 in Meerut, when Indian sepoys rebelled against the British officers.
  • This revolt was triggered by multiple factors, including the use of greased cartridges, economic exploitation, political annexation, and disrespect to Indian traditions.
  • Though the British termed it a mutiny, Indian historians consider it the first major rebellion against British colonial rule.
  • The revolt soon spread across northern and central India, involving cities like Delhi, Kanpur, Lucknow, Jhansi, and others.

Additional Information:

  • Key leaders included Rani Lakshmibai, Nana Sahib, Begum Hazrat Mahal, and Kunwar Singh.
  • Though the revolt was eventually suppressed by 1858, it shook the foundations of British rule in India.
  • As a result, the British Crown took direct control of India from the East India Company in 1858.

question:
Nana Sahib, a rebel at Kanpur, was the son of which of the following Peshwas?

SSC CGL 17/07/2023 (4th Shift)
solution:
• Nana Sahib was a prominent leader in the Revolt of 1857, particularly in Kanpur.
  • He was the adopted son of Peshwa Baji Rao II, the last Peshwa of the Maratha Empire.
  • After Baji Rao II’s death, the British denied Nana Sahib the pension that was being given to his father under the Subsidiary Alliance.
  • This injustice became a major reason for his resentment against the British and led to his active participation in the rebellion.
  • Nana Sahib led the Kanpur uprising and was initially successful in capturing the British entrenchments.

Additional Information:

  • His close associates included Tantia Tope and Azimullah Khan.
  • After the failure of the revolt in Kanpur, his whereabouts became unknown, and his fate remains a historical mystery.
  • Baji Rao II was exiled to Bithoor near Kanpur, where Nana Sahib grew up.

question:
Which Mughal ruler contributed to the revolt of 1857?

SSC CGL 25/07/2023 (4th Shift)
solution:
• The Mughal ruler who contributed to the Revolt of 1857 was Bahadur Shah II, also known as Bahadur Shah Zafar.
  • He was the last Mughal emperor and a symbolic figurehead during the rebellion.
  • On 11 May 1857, the sepoys from Meerut reached Delhi and declared Bahadur Shah Zafar as the Emperor of Hindustan.
  • Though he had little political or military power, his name gave legitimacy and unity to the rebellion.
  • After the failure of the revolt, he was captured by the British and exiled to Rangoon (present-day Yangon, Myanmar), where he died in 1862.

Additional Information:

  • Bahadur Shah Zafar was more of a poet and philosopher, not a warrior.
  • His involvement gave the revolt a national character against British rule.
  • The end of the revolt also marked the formal end of the Mughal Empire in India.

question:
The sepoys of Meerut arrived at the gates of Red Fort to meet the Mughal emperor, Bahadur Shah on _____________.

SSC MTS 16/05/2023 (Evening)
solution:
• The Revolt of 1857 began in Meerut on the evening of 10 May 1857.
  • After revolting, the sepoys marched overnight and reached the Red Fort in Delhi on the morning of 11 May 1857.
  • Their goal was to seek the support of Bahadur Shah Zafar, the Mughal emperor, and proclaim him as the leader of the uprising.
  • Upon reaching the gates of the Red Fort, the sepoys requested Bahadur Shah Zafar to lead the rebellion, giving the revolt a symbolic and national character.
  • This act helped spread the revolt across northern and central India, as it now had a central figurehead.

Additional Information:

  • The Mughal emperor initially hesitated but eventually agreed to support the rebels.
  • On 12 May 1857, Bahadur Shah Zafar issued a proclamation urging Indians to rise against British rule.
  • The arrival at Red Fort is considered a crucial turning point in the revolt's spread.

question:
Whose proclamation of November 1, 1858 declared that thereafter India would be governed by and in the name of the British Monarch through a Secretary of State?

SSC MTS 08/10/2021 (Morning)
solution:
• On 1 November 1858, a historic proclamation was made in India, known as Queen Victoria’s Proclamation.
  • It was issued after the suppression of the Revolt of 1857, formally ending the rule of the East India Company.
  • The proclamation declared that India would henceforth be governed by and in the name of the British Monarch, specifically Queen Victoria, through a newly appointed Secretary of State for India.
  • This marked the beginning of direct British Crown rule over India.
  • The announcement also promised non-interference in religious beliefs, equal treatment, and justice under the British Crown.

Additional Information:

  • The proclamation was read aloud by Lord Canning, the first Viceroy of India, in a grand durbar at Allahabad.
  • This day is also considered the beginning of the British Raj (1858–1947).
  • The newly created office of Secretary of State for India held supreme authority over Indian affairs in Britain.

question:
When was the Enfield rifle fired with greased cartridges introduced into the British Indian Army?

47th BPSC (Pre) 2005
solution:
• The Enfield rifle was introduced into the British Indian Army as a replacement for the old musket model.
  • It used .577 caliber cartridges, which had to be bitten off before loading.
  • In December 1856, the army started issuing these greased cartridges, rumored to be coated with cow and pig fat.
  • This offended both Hindu and Muslim sepoys, as it violated their religious beliefs.
  • The introduction of these cartridges became the immediate cause of the Revolt of 1857.

Additional Information:

  • The controversy began in early 1857, spreading suspicion and anger across the army.
  • The issue triggered the rebellion, starting with Mangal Pandey at Barrackpore on 29 March 1857.
  • The Enfield rifle itself was not new, but the greased cartridge issue associated with it turned into a symbol of British insensitivity to Indian faiths.

question:
The main immediate cause of India's first independence struggle was-

RAS/RTS (Pre) 1993
option_1: Lord Dalhousie's policy of annexation
option_2: Suspicion of British interference in religion
option_4: Economic exploitation of India
solution:
• The main immediate cause of India's First War of Independence (1857) was the suspicion among Indian sepoys that the British were attempting to interfere with their religion.
  • This fear was triggered by the introduction of the Enfield rifle, whose cartridges were believed to be greased with cow and pig fat.
  • Hindus considered cows sacred, and Muslims considered pigs impure, making this act deeply offensive to both communities.
  • The British forced sepoys to bite these cartridges, which was viewed as a deliberate attack on their faith.
  • This religious outrage, combined with simmering military and social tensions, ignited the revolt.

Additional Information:

  • Though there were other underlying causes—economic exploitation, political annexation, and military dissatisfaction—the religious fear was the immediate spark.
  • This suspicion was further fueled by events like Mangal Pandey's revolt at Barrackpore on 29 March 1857.
  • Many Indians believed the British were trying to convert the population to Christianity, increasing unrest.

question:
Mangal Pandey's incident happened-

Uttarakhand PCS (Mains) 2002
solution:
• The Mangal Pandey incident took place at Barrackpore (near Kolkata) on 29 March 1857.
  • Mangal Pandey was a sepoy in the 34th Bengal Native Infantry of the British Indian Army.
  • He rebelled against British officers, refusing to use the greased cartridges associated with the newly introduced Enfield rifles.
  • He attacked a British officer and tried to incite other soldiers to revolt.
  • Mangal Pandey was eventually captured, court-martialled, and hanged on 8 April 1857.

Additional Information:

  • Mangal Pandey’s action is considered the first spark of the Revolt of 1857.
  • Although the revolt formally began later in Meerut on 10 May 1857, Pandey’s rebellion was its symbolic beginning.
  • He is often referred to as a hero and martyr in Indian history.

question:
Mangal Pandey is associated with which rebellion?

UP PCS (Pre) 2010
option_4: None of the above
solution:
• Mangal Pandey is historically associated with the Barrackpore rebellion of 29 March 1857.
  • He was a sepoy in the 34th Bengal Native Infantry of the British Indian Army.
  • He is remembered for revolting against British officers, primarily in protest against the use of greased cartridges believed to contain cow and pig fat.
  • His actions at Barrackpore are considered the first act of defiance leading up to the Revolt of 1857.
  • He was later arrested, court-martialled, and executed on 8 April 1857.

Additional Information:

  • Though the main revolt began in Meerut on 10 May 1857, Mangal Pandey’s defiance is regarded as its symbolic beginning.
  • The place Barrackpore, near Kolkata (then Calcutta), became a significant location in India’s freedom struggle because of this incident.
  • He is honored as one of the first martyrs of India’s struggle for independence.

question:
Mangal Pandey was a soldier-

UPPSC (RI) 2014
solution:
• Mangal Pandey was a soldier in the 34th Bengal Native Infantry of the British Indian Army.
  • He is most famously associated with the incident at Barrackpore on 29 March 1857, which is considered the precursor to the Revolt of 1857.
  • His rebellion was sparked by the introduction of greased cartridges used in Enfield rifles, believed to contain cow and pig fat, which violated Hindu and Muslim religious beliefs.
  • Mangal Pandey attacked British officers and attempted to incite fellow soldiers to join the revolt.
  • He was arrested, tried by court-martial, and executed on 8 April 1857.

Additional Information:

  • Mangal Pandey’s act is often referred to as the first spark of India’s First War of Independence.
  • The 34th BNI (Bengal Native Infantry) was later disbanded after the incident.
  • Mangal Pandey is commemorated in Indian history as a patriot and martyr.

question:
To whom did Bahadur Shah give the title of 'Sahib-e-Alam Bahadur' during the revolt of 1857?

UP RO/ARO (Pre) 2016
solution:
• During the Revolt of 1857, Bahadur Shah Zafar, the last Mughal emperor, became the symbolic leader of the uprising.
  • He bestowed the title ‘Sahib-e-Alam Bahadur’ upon Bakht Khan, recognizing his leadership and military skills.
  • Bakht Khan was a sepoy subedar in the British East India Company's army and later became the commander-in-chief of the rebel forces in Delhi.
  • He arrived in Delhi from Bareilly with a large contingent of troops and took charge of organizing the rebel forces under the nominal authority of Bahadur Shah.
  • The title meant "Lord of the Universe, the Brave", symbolizing his elevated status in the rebel hierarchy.

Additional Information:

  • Bakht Khan attempted to bring discipline and structure to the disorganized rebel army in Delhi.
  • Despite his efforts, internal conflicts and lack of unified leadership weakened the rebel command.
  • He is remembered as one of the key military leaders of the 1857 revolt.

question:
What was the main reason for the revolt of 1857?

UP PCS (Pre) 1990
option_3: Management of Christian missionaries
option_4: Policy of the British Empire
solution:
• The main reason for the Revolt of 1857 was the overall policy of the British Empire that led to widespread dissatisfaction across different sections of Indian society.
  • These policies included:
    • The Doctrine of Lapse, used by Lord Dalhousie to annex Indian princely states like Jhansi and Satara.
    • Heavy taxation, exploitation of farmers, and destruction of traditional industries.
    • Disrespect toward Indian customs, traditions, and religions, creating deep mistrust.
    • Political annexations, especially the abolition of titles and privileges of Indian rulers.
  • While military discontent and religious interference were immediate triggers, the underlying cause was the imperialist and exploitative policies of British rule.

Additional Information:

  • The revolt had multiple causes: political, economic, social, religious, and military.
  • The introduction of greased cartridges was the immediate cause, but the foundation of resentment was built over years of oppressive policies.
  • The revolt became a widespread movement due to shared grievances against British imperialism.

question:
Who was the correspondent of the London-based newspaper 'Times' who wrote in 1857 that 'In Northern India no one looked with friendly eyes at the white man's carriage’?

MPPCS (Pre) 2020
solution:
• The correspondent of the London-based newspaper 'The Times' who covered the Revolt of 1857 was W.H. Russell (William Howard Russell).
  • He is regarded as one of the first modern war correspondents and reported extensively from northern India during the revolt.
  • In 1857, W.H. Russell wrote,

    "In Northern India no one looked with friendly eyes at the white man's carriage."

    This reflected the deep resentment and anger of the Indian people toward British rule.

  • His writings provided the British public with firsthand accounts of the rebellion and its brutal suppression.

Additional Information:

  • Russell earlier gained fame for his coverage of the Crimean War.
  • His reports from India highlighted both the brutality of the rebels and the repressive retaliation by the British.
  • His work played a key role in shaping British opinion about colonial governance and military conduct in India.

question:
Where did the revolution of 1857 first start?

UP PCS (Pre) 1990, 1994
solution:
• The Revolt of 1857, also known as the First War of Indian Independence, first began in Meerut on the evening of 10 May 1857.
  • The revolt started when Indian sepoys in the British army rebelled against their British officers.
  • The immediate cause was the use of greased cartridges in the new Enfield rifles, which hurt religious sentiments of both Hindus and Muslims.
  • The sepoys broke into revolt, freed fellow soldiers from jail, killed British officers, and marched toward Delhi the same night.
  • This incident marked the official beginning of the large-scale uprising against British rule.

Additional Information:

  • The revolt quickly spread to Delhi, Kanpur, Lucknow, Jhansi, and other parts of northern and central India.
  • Bahadur Shah Zafar was declared the emperor by the rebels when they reached Delhi on 11 May 1857.
  • While the uprising had multiple causes, Meerut is recognized as the starting point of the actual armed rebellion.

question:
Which of the following assurances by Queen Victoria's 1858 proclamation was fulfilled?

UP PCS (Pre) 1994
option_2: Status quo for princely states
option_3: Equal treatment for Indians and Europeans
option_4: No interference in religious beliefs
solution:
• In her Proclamation of 1858, Queen Victoria assured several reforms in the governance of India after the Revolt of 1857.
  • Among these, the abolition of the Doctrine of Lapse (annexation policy) was the only assurance fully implemented.
  • This meant that Indian princely states were allowed to adopt heirs and were not annexed arbitrarily by the British anymore.
  • This fulfilled a major demand of the Indian rulers, many of whom had lost their states due to Lord Dalhousie’s annexation policy.

Additional Information:

  • Other promises in the proclamation, like equal treatment for Indians and Europeans and no interference in religious beliefs, were partially followed or ignored in practice.
  • The status quo for princely states was maintained conditionally, but the British retained significant control.
  • The proclamation was read by Lord Canning in Allahabad and marked the formal beginning of British Crown rule in India.

question:
The first incident related to the freedom struggle of 1857 was-

UP PCS (Mains) 2008
option_1: Kanpur revolt & Nana Saheb's leadership
option_2: Begum Hazrat Mahal leads Awadh
option_3: Troops arriving at Red Fort, Delhi
option_4: Revolt of Rani of Jhansi
solution:
• The first major incident that gave the Revolt of 1857 a national character was when the rebel sepoys from Meerut reached the Red Fort in Delhi on 11 May 1857.
  • They appealed to the Mughal emperor Bahadur Shah Zafar to lead the uprising.
  • This event marked the symbolic beginning of the freedom struggle, as it brought the Mughal dynasty back into focus and united various rebel forces under a common figurehead.
  • Although earlier events like Mangal Pandey’s revolt or Meerut mutiny occurred before this, the arrival at the Red Fort was the first organized act that gave direction to the rebellion.

Additional Information:

  • Bahadur Shah Zafar, though reluctant initially, accepted the leadership and was declared the Emperor of Hindustan.
  • This event inspired revolts in Kanpur (Nana Saheb), Jhansi (Rani Lakshmibai), Awadh (Begum Hazrat Mahal) and other regions.
  • The occupation of Delhi gave the revolt a pan-Indian scope and is often treated as the starting point of the coordinated freedom struggle.

question:
Which of the following was not a reason for sepoy rebellion?

BPSC (Pre) 2018
option_2: Travel order on ships
solution:
• The Sepoy Rebellion of 1857 (also known as the First War of Indian Independence) had several causes, but “inefficiency of officials” was not one of the key reasons.
  • The main causes of sepoy discontent included:
    • Religious concerns, like the fear of forced Christian conversion and use of greased cartridges.
    • General Service Enlistment Act (1856), which required sepoys to cross the sea (Kala Pani), violating religious beliefs.
    • Economic issues, such as withholding of allowances and poor pay compared to British soldiers.
  • These reasons created a sense of betrayal and fear among the Indian sepoys.

Additional Information:

  • The cartridge issue was the immediate cause, but long-term grievances regarding religion, pay, promotion, and respect built up over time.
  • The British had also started interfering in social customs, adding to the resentment.
  • Inefficiency of British officials, although a general administrative flaw, was not cited by sepoys as a direct cause of rebellion.

question:
The symbol of the freedom struggle of 1857 was-

MPPCS (Pre) 1990
solution:
• The symbol of the freedom struggle of 1857 was the lotus and chapati (bread).
  • These were used as secret signals among Indian villagers and sepoys to spread the message of an impending revolt.
  • The lotus flower was typically passed among Hindu soldiers, while chapatis (rotis) were distributed among villagers as a mysterious sign.
  • Although their exact meaning was unclear, they created a sense of unity and anticipation across northern India.
  • This symbolic communication helped mobilize rural and military support for the rebellion.

Additional Information:

  • The British were confused and alarmed by this strange circulation of chapatis and lotuses.
  • The movement was silent and rapid, creating anxiety within the British administration.
  • These items were not weapons but served as psychological tools to unify Indians against colonial rule.

question:
Which of the following centres of the War of 1857 was first recaptured by the British?

UPPCS (Mains) 2015
solution:
• Among the major centers of the Revolt of 1857, Delhi was the first to be recaptured by the British.
  • The rebel sepoys had seized Delhi on 11 May 1857 and declared Bahadur Shah Zafar as their emperor.
  • The British launched a massive military campaign to regain control over the city.
  • After a prolonged siege and intense fighting, Delhi was recaptured on 20 September 1857.
  • The fall of Delhi dealt a major blow to the morale of the rebels, as it was the symbolic capital of the uprising.

Additional Information:

  • After Delhi, the British proceeded to recapture other centers like Kanpur, Lucknow, and Jhansi.
  • Bahadur Shah Zafar was captured, tried, and exiled to Rangoon (modern-day Yangon).
  • The recapture of Delhi marked the beginning of the decline of the 1857 revolt.

question:
The birthplace of Maharani Laxmibai is-

UPPCS (Spl.) (Pre) 2008
solution:
• Maharani Lakshmibai, one of the most iconic figures of the Revolt of 1857, was born in Varanasi (Kashi) on 19 November 1828.
  • Her birth name was Manikarnika Tambe, and she was affectionately called Manu in her childhood.
  • She later became the Queen of Jhansi after marrying Gangadhar Rao, the ruler of Jhansi.
  • Despite being born in Varanasi, she is most associated with Jhansi, where she led a fierce resistance against British forces during the 1857 revolt.

Additional Information:

  • She received training in horse riding, swordsmanship, and archery from an early age.
  • After her husband’s death and the British refusal to recognize her adopted son as heir, she declared, "I will not give up my Jhansi."
  • She died fighting bravely on 17 June 1858 near Gwalior and is remembered as a symbol of courage and patriotism.

question:
Who was the leader of the Bareilly revolt of 1857?

UP PCS (Pre) 1998
solution:
• The leader of the Bareilly revolt during the 1857 uprising was Khan Bahadur Khan.
  • He was the grandson of Hafiz Rahmat Khan, a former Rohilla leader, and played a key role in the Rohilkhand region’s resistance against British rule.
  • Khan Bahadur Khan declared himself the Nawab of Rohilkhand and set up a parallel administration during the revolt.
  • He organized rebel forces in Bareilly and gave stiff resistance to the British until the city was recaptured in 1858.
  • His leadership in Bareilly was marked by strong administration and military resistance during the 1857 rebellion.

Additional Information:

  • Khan Bahadur was eventually captured by the British and executed in 1860.
  • Bareilly was one of the major centers of the revolt in northern India.
  • His contribution is considered vital in keeping the spirit of resistance alive in Rohilkhand during the revolt.

question:
Who was the leader of the 1857 revolution in Bareilly, UP?

UP PCS (Pre) 2023
solution:
• The leader of the 1857 revolt in Bareilly (Uttar Pradesh) was Khan Bahadur Khan.
  • He was a descendant of Rohilla chief Hafiz Rahmat Khan and had administrative experience under the British before joining the rebellion.
  • In 1857, Khan Bahadur Khan declared himself the independent Nawab of Rohilkhand and took command of rebel forces in the region.
  • He established a parallel government in Bareilly and resisted British rule through organized military actions.
  • Bareilly remained a significant center of resistance under his leadership until it was recaptured by the British in 1858.

Additional Information:

  • Khan Bahadur Khan was captured and executed in 1860 by the British.
  • His administration attempted to enforce justice and order, even during the rebellion.
  • He is remembered as a strong and determined leader who represented the Rohilla Muslim community’s resistance to colonial rule.

question:
Where is the tomb of Maharani Laxmibai located?

MPPCS (Pre) 2013
solution:
• The tomb of Maharani Lakshmibai is located in Gwalior, Madhya Pradesh.
  • She died fighting bravely on 17 June 1858 near Kotah-ki-Serai, during a battle with British forces.
  • After her martyrdom, she was cremated at a place near Phool Bagh in Gwalior, where a memorial (samadhi) now stands in her honor.
  • This location is visited as a site of national pride, symbolizing her courage and sacrifice in India’s First War of Independence.

Additional Information:

  • Maharani Lakshmibai led the defense of Jhansi during the 1857 revolt and later fought alongside Tantia Tope and Rani of Tirwa.
  • She wore male attire during battle and is remembered for her famous statement:

    "Main apni Jhansi nahi doongi" (I will not give up my Jhansi).

  • Her memorial in Gwalior includes a statue on horseback with a drawn sword, honoring her as a symbol of bravery.

question:
Where did Rani Lakshmi Bai of Jhansi die?

67th BPSC (Pre) (Re-Exam), 2021
option_5: None of the above/More than one of the above
solution:
• Rani Lakshmi Bai of Jhansi died in Gwalior on 17 June 1858.
  • During the Revolt of 1857, after the British attacked and captured Jhansi, she fled and joined forces with Tantia Tope and other rebel leaders.
  • She reached Gwalior, where she fought valiantly against the British forces near Kotah-ki-Serai.
  • Dressed in male warrior attire, she led her troops courageously and was mortally wounded in battle.
  • She became a symbol of resistance and is remembered for her heroic stand against colonial rule.

Additional Information:

  • After her death, she was cremated near Phool Bagh, Gwalior, where a memorial now exists in her honor.
  • British General Hugh Rose, who fought against her, remarked:

    "She was the bravest and best military leader of the rebels."

  • Her bravery and patriotism made her a legendary figure in India’s freedom struggle.

question:
Rani Laxmi Bai had to face whom in her last battle?

MPPCS (Pre) 1992
solution:
• In her last battle, Rani Lakshmi Bai faced Sir Hugh Rose, a senior British general.
  • This confrontation took place during the Battle of Gwalior in June 1858, as part of the final phase of the Revolt of 1857.
  • Hugh Rose led the Central India Field Force and launched an attack to retake Gwalior from the rebels, which included forces led by Rani Lakshmi Bai.
  • During the fierce fighting near Kotah-ki-Serai, Rani Lakshmi Bai was critically wounded and died on 17 June 1858.
  • Hugh Rose later praised her as the "best and bravest of all the rebel leaders."

Additional Information:

  • Rani Lakshmi Bai showed exceptional valor, fighting on horseback with a sword in hand.
  • She played a major role in mobilizing resistance even after losing Jhansi.
  • Her resistance at Gwalior remains a defining moment in the history of India’s First War of Independence.

question:
Under whose leadership did the revolt of 1857 proceed in Lucknow?

48th to 52nd BPSC (Pre) 2008
solution:
• The Revolt of 1857 in Lucknow was led by Begum Hazrat Mahal, also known as the Begum of Awadh.
  • She was the wife of Nawab Wajid Ali Shah, who had been exiled to Calcutta by the British after the annexation of Awadh under the Doctrine of Lapse.
  • During the revolt, she took charge of the resistance in Awadh and declared her son Birjis Qadr as the ruler.
  • Begum Hazrat Mahal established a rebel government in Lucknow and played a key role in organizing troops and maintaining control of the city for several months.

Additional Information:

  • She allied with other leaders like Maulvi Ahmadullah Shah to defend Lucknow against British attacks.
  • Despite strong resistance, the British eventually recaptured Lucknow in 1858.
  • Begum Hazrat Mahal fled to Nepal after the fall of Lucknow and remained in exile until her death.

question:
The woman who led the 1857 revolution in Awadh-

Uttarakhand PCS (Pre) 2010
solution:

  • When the Revolt of 1857 broke out, she took charge of the rebellion in Awadh and declared her son Birjis Qadr as the ruler.
  • She became the political and military face of the resistance in Lucknow and surrounding areas.
  • Begum Hazrat Mahal actively organized troops and collaborated with leaders like Maulvi Ahmadullah Shah to resist British forces.

Additional Information:

question:
Who led the freedom struggle of 1857 in Lucknow?

UPPCS (Pre) (Re-Exam) 2015
solution:
• The freedom struggle of 1857 in Lucknow was led by Begum Hazrat Mahal, also known as the Begum of Awadh.

  • Begum Hazrat Mahal played a central role in organizing resistance against the British from Lucknow, establishing a rebel administration.

question:
Who led the revolt of 1857 in Allahabad?

UPPCS (Mains) 2015
solution:
• The Revolt of 1857 in Allahabad was led by Maulvi Liaquat Ali, a prominent local leader and religious scholar.
  • He was a descendant of Prophet Muhammad and held considerable influence among the Muslim population of the region.
  • During the rebellion, he captured Allahabad and declared himself the Governor of the city on behalf of the Mughal emperor Bahadur Shah Zafar.
  • Maulvi Liaquat Ali organized local forces and resisted British authority until Allahabad was retaken by British troops.

Additional Information:

  • He continued to fight even after losing Allahabad, but was eventually captured in 1871 and died in captivity.
  • His leadership in Allahabad gave the rebellion a strong foothold in the eastern part of Uttar Pradesh.
  • He is remembered as a dedicated freedom fighter and one of the earliest revolutionaries of the 1857 uprising.

question:
Which region contributed the largest number of soldiers in 1857 struggle?

UP Lower Sub (Pre) 2015
solution:
• The region that contributed the largest number of soldiers in the Revolt of 1857 was Awadh (Oudh).
  • At the time, Awadh was a major recruitment ground for the Bengal Army of the British East India Company.
  • A significant portion of the sepoys who revolted in 1857 were from Awadh, especially due to:
    • The annexation of Awadh by Lord Dalhousie in 1856.
    • The displacement of the Nawab and disrespect shown to local nobility and traditions.
  • The population of Awadh, including landlords (Taluqdars), peasants, and dispossessed soldiers, played a central role in fueling the uprising.

Additional Information:

  • The British annexation of Awadh was deeply unpopular and seen as an insult to both the rulers and the people.
  • Major leaders like Begum Hazrat Mahal emerged from Awadh and led the rebellion from Lucknow.
  • Awadh became one of the strongest and most persistent centers of the 1857 rebellion.

question:
Who was Nana Saheb's "commander-in-chief"?

UP Lower Sub (Spl.) (Pre) 2008
option_4: None of the above
solution:
• Tatya Tope was the commander-in-chief of Nana Saheb’s forces during the Revolt of 1857.
  • He played a key role in military campaigns against the British, especially in Kanpur and Central India.
  • After the British recaptured Kanpur, Tatya Tope continued guerrilla warfare and fought alongside leaders like Rani Lakshmibai.
  • He was known for his brilliant tactics, resilience, and mobility, which helped the rebels challenge British forces for a long time.

Additional Information:

  • Tatya Tope was eventually betrayed, captured, and executed in 1859.
  • His full name was Ramachandra Pandurang Tope, and he was a close associate of Nana Saheb.
  • He is remembered as one of the most skilled military commanders of the 1857 revolt.

question:
Azimullah Khan was the advisor to-

Uttarakhand PCS (Pre) 2012
solution:
• Azimullah Khan was the advisor and political emissary to Nana Saheb, one of the key leaders of the Revolt of 1857.
  • He played a significant role in shaping Nana Saheb’s political strategy and advised him on military and diplomatic affairs.
  • Azimullah was earlier sent to London in 1853 to appeal for the restoration of Nana Saheb’s adopted father Baji Rao II's pension, which the British had discontinued.
  • His mission failed, but he returned with a strong anti-British sentiment and helped plan resistance.

Additional Information:

  • Azimullah was a journalist and well-versed in English, which made him a valuable asset to Nana Saheb.
  • He was involved in the planning of the Kanpur uprising during the 1857 revolt.
  • His strategic insight helped Nana Saheb establish his position as a prominent rebel leader.

question:
Who among the following was betrayed by a friend and killed by the British during 1857 revolt?

IAS (Pre) 2006
solution:
• Tatya Tope, a key military leader in the Revolt of 1857, was betrayed by a close associate and eventually captured by the British.
  • After continued resistance through guerrilla warfare in Central India, he was handed over to the British by Man Singh, a local chieftain of Narwar, in exchange for personal gains.
  • Tatya Tope was arrested, tried in a British military court, and executed by hanging on 18 April 1859.
  • He had been a loyal and skilled commander, especially known as the commander-in-chief under Nana Saheb.

Additional Information:

  • His real name was Ramachandra Pandurang Tope.
  • He was involved in major battles across Kanpur, Jhansi, and Gwalior, and supported Rani Lakshmibai.
  • Despite losing key positions, he continued guerrilla attacks for over a year after the main revolt had subsided.

question:
Who among the following revolutionaries of 1857 was actually named 'Ramachandra Pandurang’?

UP UDA/LDA (Pre) 2010, UPPCS (Pre) 2011
solution:
• The revolutionary of the 1857 revolt who was actually named 'Ramachandra Pandurang' was Tatya Tope.
  • Tatya Tope was his popular revolutionary name, while his full name was Ramachandra Pandurang Tope.
  • He was one of the most prominent military leaders of the revolt and served as the commander-in-chief under Nana Saheb.
  • He led major campaigns in Kanpur, supported Rani Lakshmibai in Jhansi and Gwalior, and later conducted guerrilla warfare against the British in central India.

Additional Information:

  • He continued to fight the British even after the fall of major rebel centers.
  • He was betrayed by Man Singh of Narwar, captured, and later executed on 18 April 1859.
  • Tatya Tope is remembered for his bravery, loyalty, and military genius during the First War of Indian Independence.

question:
Kunwar Singh was a major hero of the revolt of 1857. He was associated with which of the following?

IAS (Pre) 2005
solution:
• Kunwar Singh was one of the most prominent leaders of the Revolt of 1857 and was associated with the region of Bihar.
  • He was the Zamindar of Jagdishpur, located in present-day Bhojpur district, Bihar.
  • Despite being around 80 years old, he led a valiant armed resistance against the British forces in Bihar and eastern India.
  • Kunwar Singh carried out guerrilla warfare, harassed British supply lines, and conducted campaigns even while wounded.

Additional Information:

  • He is often referred to as the "Lion of Bihar" for his bravery and leadership.
  • During one battle, he was injured in the arm, which he later amputated himself to prevent infection.
  • His heroic resistance inspired many others in eastern India to rise against colonial rule.

question:
Kunwar Singh, a leader of the revolt of 1857, belonged to which place?

67th B.P.S.C. (Pre), 2021
option_5: None of the above/More than one of the above
solution:
• Kunwar Singh, one of the leading figures of the Revolt of 1857, belonged to Jagdishpur, a town in the present-day Bhojpur district of Bihar.
  • He was a Zamindar (landlord) of Jagdishpur and played a crucial role in organizing armed resistance against the British in eastern India.
  • At the age of around 80 years, he led the Bihar-based uprising and inflicted significant damage on British forces through guerilla tactics and open battles.

Additional Information:

  • He is often honored as the "Lion of Bihar" due to his bravery and leadership.
  • Even after being wounded, he continued to lead troops and amputated his own injured arm to prevent infection.
  • His revolt spread across Bihar, eastern Uttar Pradesh, and touched parts of Central India.

question:
Where did Kunwar Singh participate in the rebellion of 1857 against the British?

64th B.P.S.C. (Pre) 2018
option_5: None of the above/More than one of the above
solution:
• Kunwar Singh actively participated in the Revolt of 1857 against the British in the region of Arrah (Aara), located in present-day Bhojpur district, Bihar.
  • As the Zamindar of Jagdishpur, which is near Arrah, Kunwar Singh led a large force of rebels and organized attacks on British establishments.
  • The most notable event was the Siege of Arrah, where British forces were trapped and besieged by Kunwar Singh’s troops in July 1857.
  • His leadership in the Arrah region was marked by military strategy, local support, and relentless resistance.

Additional Information:

  • Despite his age (around 80 years), Kunwar Singh led his troops with remarkable energy.
  • The British faced a strong setback in Arrah, and the event became a symbol of local resistance.
  • He is honored as one of the most respected freedom fighters of Bihar and eastern India.

question:
Who was the leader of the revolutionaries in Bihar during the revolution of 1857?

B.P.C.S. (Pre.) 2016
option_5: None of the above/More than one of the above
solution:

  • He was the Zamindar of Jagdishpur (in present-day Bhojpur district) and played a central role in organizing the rebellion in Bihar.
  • Despite being around 80 years old, Kunwar Singh led rebel forces against the British with great courage and strategic acumen.
  • His participation included the Siege of Arrah and guerrilla warfare across Bihar and parts of eastern India.

Additional Information:

  • Kunwar Singh is honored as the "Lion of Bihar".
  • Even after being wounded in battle, he amputated his own hand to prevent infection and continued to lead.

question:

45th B.P.S.C. (Pre) 2001
solution:

  • His leadership and military efforts played a vital role in spreading the revolt across Bihar and parts of eastern Uttar Pradesh.

question:
Which person from Jagdishpur led the revolutionaries in the revolt of 1857 AD?

48th to 52nd B.P.S.C. (Pre) 2008
solution:
• The person from Jagdishpur who led the revolutionaries during the Revolt of 1857 was Kunwar Singh.
  • He was a Zamindar (landlord) of Jagdishpur, located in the present-day Bhojpur district of Bihar.
  • At around 80 years of age, Kunwar Singh became one of the most prominent leaders of the 1857 uprising in eastern India.
  • He led the rebellion in Bihar, organized attacks on British forces, and famously conducted the Siege of Arrah.

Additional Information:

  • Despite his age and injuries, he continued fighting and even amputated his own wounded hand to prevent infection.
  • Kunwar Singh is revered as the “Lion of Bihar” and remains a symbol of resistance and bravery in India’s freedom struggle.
  • None of the other names (Chandrashekhar, Tirat Singh, Ram Singh) are associated with leadership roles in the 1857 revolt in Jagdishpur.

question:
The king of Jagdishpur was-

43rd B.P.S.C. (Pre) 1999
solution:
• The king (Zamindar) of Jagdishpur during the Revolt of 1857 was Kunwar Singh.
  • Jagdishpur, located in the present-day Bhojpur district of Bihar, was his ancestral estate.
  • Kunwar Singh was around 80 years old when he led the rebellion against the British, making him one of the most senior leaders of the revolt.
  • He played a pivotal role in organizing resistance in Bihar and eastern India and is remembered for his valiant efforts in the Siege of Arrah.

  • Despite his age and injuries, Kunwar Singh displayed extraordinary bravery, even amputating his own wounded hand during battle.

question:
The leader of the 1857 freedom struggle of Patna was-

43rd B.P.S.C. (Pre) 1999
solution:
• The leader of the 1857 freedom struggle in the Patna region was Rajput Kunwar Singh.
  • Though Kunwar Singh's primary base was Jagdishpur in the Bhojpur district of Bihar, his influence and operations extended across large parts of Bihar, including Patna.
  • He was a Zamindar (landlord) and a prominent military leader during the revolt, known for his strategic acumen and unyielding spirit, even at the age of around 80.
  • Kunwar Singh coordinated with other rebels in Arrah, Patna, and nearby areas to lead the resistance against the British.

Additional Information:

  • Despite his age, Kunwar Singh actively led troops and used guerrilla warfare against the British.
  • He became a symbol of courage and is widely honored as the "Lion of Bihar."

question:
Who among the following was the leader of the 1857 revolution in Assam?

U.P. P.C.S. (Mains) 2007
solution:
• The leader of the 1857 revolution in Assam was Diwan Maniram Dutt.
  • He was originally an official in the Ahom royal court and later became a Diwan under the British administration.
  • Discontented with British rule, especially after being dismissed from service, he became actively involved in anti-British activities during the 1857 revolt.
  • Maniram Dutt played a key role in mobilizing public sentiment and organizing resistance against the British in Assam.
  • He supported the restoration of the Ahom monarchy and worked to reinstate Kandarpeshwar Singh (Ahom prince).

Additional Information:

  • Maniram Dutt was arrested for his revolutionary activities and executed by hanging in 1858 at Jorhat.
  • He is remembered as one of the first martyrs from Assam in the Indian freedom struggle.
  • Piyali Barua, his close associate, was also executed.

question:
The center of the revolt of 1857 in Bihar from 15 July 1857 to 20 January 1858 was-

43rd B.P.S.C. (Pre) 1999
solution:
• The center of the Revolt of 1857 in Bihar from 15 July 1857 to 20 January 1858 was Jagdishpur.
  • Jagdishpur, located in the present-day Bhojpur district of Bihar, was the stronghold of Babu Kunwar Singh, one of the foremost leaders of the 1857 uprising.
  • Kunwar Singh led a prolonged and organized resistance against British forces from this region.
  • Under his leadership, Jagdishpur remained a major hub of revolutionary activity during this critical period of the revolt.

Additional Information:

  • The revolt in Jagdishpur was marked by strategic guerrilla warfare, frequent skirmishes, and popular support from local people.
  • Even after the fall of other major centers, resistance in Jagdishpur continued, showing the strength of Kunwar Singh’s leadership.
  • The British finally reasserted control over the region in early 1858, shortly after Kunwar Singh’s final campaigns.

question:
The one who defeated the joint army of British and Jodhpur in the revolution of 1857 AD was-

R.A.S./R.T.S. (Pre) 1993
option_2: Nawab Wazir Khan of Tonk
option_4: Thakur Kushal Singh of Auwa
solution:
• The person who defeated the joint army of the British and the Jodhpur state during the Revolt of 1857 was Thakur Kushal Singh of Auwa.
  • Auwa, located in present-day Pali district of Rajasthan, became a significant center of rebellion under his leadership.
  • Thakur Kushal Singh mobilized local Rajput forces and successfully repelled attacks by the combined forces of the British and the Jodhpur state.

Battle Highlights:

  • He notably defeated the army led by General Lawrence and the forces of Maharaja Takht Singh of Jodhpur.
  • After the defeat, the British launched a massive counter-attack and laid siege to Auwa fort.
  • Eventually, Auwa fell in late 1857, but Kushal Singh escaped and continued resistance from the hills of Sirohi.

Additional Information:

  • Thakur Kushal Singh is remembered as a valiant Rajput warrior who defied British imperial power.
  • His role in Rajasthan’s contribution to the 1857 revolt is significant, although lesser-known nationally.
  • The fort of Auwa became a symbol of resistance during the rebellion.
